Description: Digital photograph (colour); detail of u rock art on rock surface (sandstone?) showing three human and seventeen cattle figures mostly infilled in dark and light brown and one unidentified shape. Top (left to right): light cow turned on side and facing up with back to right, light upright human figure wearing skirt, dark cow turned to side and facing down with back to upper right, unidentified light arced shape, upright dark cow facing right. Centre (left to right): upside down light cow facing left with infilled prominent udder, vertical line through trunk and outward curved horns. Light cow turned to side and facing up with back to right with infilled udder. Dark human figure, upright, facing left with unidentified arc projecting from chest (arms?), four further dark upright cows. Bottom (left to right): Two upright cows facing left, one facing right, dark brown upright human figure with elbows bent and arms raised, cow with calf between legs upright and facing right, upright cow facing left with faded white belly and rump of cow turned to side and facing down with back to right. Several figures are very faded/eroded. Karkur Talh, Sudan. Scanned
Curator's comments: Detail of 2013,2034.220. Karkur Tahl is the largest wadi (dry seasonal riverbed valley) in the sandstone eastern section of Jebel Uweinat, a granite and sandstone massif on the border of Egypt, Libya and Sudan. Karkur Talh is around 25 km long and lies mostly in Sudan, but partly within Egypt’s borders. There is an abundance of both painted and engraved rock art in shelters in the smaller side wadis. The engravings were first revealed to academia by Ahmed Hassanein in 1923 and a few photographs published in his report on the journey in National Geographic in 1924. A more comprehensive publication of rock art sites in Karkur Talh was made by Prince Kemal el Dine with Abbe Breuil in 1925 following his discovery of a painted cave in Karkur Talh. Further exploration and publications were made by numerous others including renowned explorer Ralph Bagnold’s expedition in 1931, with further exploration from László Almásy and Leo Frobenius in 1933. The largest professional exploration of the massif to date was made in 1968 by a team of Belgian scientists.
Acquisition name: Donated by: Trust for African Rock Art
